Şimdi bakalım neden böyle oldu, bu oyun oynanır mı? Oyunda çatılarda atlaya zıplaya gezen bir grubun üyesiyiz. Daha sonra karşılaştığımız birtakım komploları çözmeye çalışıyoruz. Böylesi bir parkur oyunundan kuvvetli bir hikaye beklemiyordum, ancak olay örgüsü güzel kurulmuş ve başarılı işlenmiş. Bazı yerler tahmin edilebilir olabiliyor, bazen mantık hataları gözlenebiliyor ama yine de tatmin edici bir hikaye anlatımı var. Özellikle ara sahnelerde anlatımı güçlendiren animasyonlar da hoş olmuş. Problem burada başlıyor. Böylesi bir parkur oyununda sağlam mekanikler olmazsa çıldırabiliyorsunuz. Nitekim bu oyunda da böyle bir problem var. Bazı yerlerde diyorsunuz ki \"Ben buradan şöyle atlar çıkarım burayı\". Ama olmuyor, oyunun çizdiği belli başlı yolları izlemek zorunda kalıyorsunuz. Çok kolay bir biçimde tutunabileceği yerlere tutunamayıp 75 metre düşen bir karakter oluyorsunuz sonra. Oyundaki dövüş mekaniği de ayrı bir sıkıntı. Dövüş animasyonu, çokça düşmanla karşılaştığınız yerlerde başınıza bela oluyor. Bütün bunlar beni bir o yana bir bu yana götürdü. Olumsuz buçuktan olumlu bir inceleme yazayım diyordum. {"text": "Dont buy the game just because of the multiplayer (i have 77 hours of multiplayer) Singleplayer works fine, and the story is ok :)  Multiplayer Review: What i like about the multiplayer: The setting, the futuristic stuff, the sci fi stuff, the fast paced gameplay, the movement, the third dimension (maps are big and vertical also)  Problems i had with the game: ( i want to say that my pc is as good as recommended hardware, win10, everything updated, clean pc, dual monitors) - The game is freezing, like a lot, unplayable, every 10 seconds or so, a half a second freeze. especially the game is freezing when the new map start, its is like insane, you cant even move right.  i thought it was a hardware problem, but it isnt, i have purchased a new gpu, the game works the same, the fix for this is to uninstall the game (remove it completely, verify integrity cache doesnt help) and then redownload all 50GB of the game. (i dont mind the download) but after a few days, the game starts freezing again, which drives you nuts. and if you want, you can repeat the process :D - The game is crashing, yeah, for a lot, and for a lot of weird reasons.  1. not enough memory crash, i have 12GB of ram, and the game is crashing because i dont have enough memory, even if you have 64GB of RAM it will still crash and give you not enough memory message, Fix is, you need to enable PAGE FILE (i know, doesnt make any sense) set at least 2GB of virtual memory and the game will stop crashing with that error message. 2. the gpu crash, when the game crashes, the screen goes black, and you need to restart your pc, (enabling page file fixes this) i dont understand that one also.  3. the random crash, i have no idea, regular windows error closed this program... they happen from time to time, especially if you chat on steam (using the steam overlay) a lot when you play - The game is lagging, i mean, when you play a faced paced game like this, everyone needs to have a good connection in order for a game to be ok, but that is not the issue 1. i can understand that after 1 year passes the game loses its players 2. there are no dedicated servers, so most of the time you are connected to some guy (who is the server)  3. half of the players have a bad connection to the server, 2 or 3 bars out of 4 (bars show how good the ping is) 4. most of the time i have 4 bars(max), and other people are like skipping frames, i see him here, then i see him there 5. in a fast paced game like this it is really hard to play like this - {"text": "I REALLY wanted to like this game. It has great graphics and it's built well, it has good voice acting, and it isn't buggy. It is also published by Daedalic which I like. But sadly, it is just plain boring. The story is simply terrible, repeating itself, barely any twists, boring ending. The dialogs are WAY too long and boring, most of them have no effect on the storyline and are just wasting your time, yet you can't progress unless you listen to all of them. Every time you click a character you are stuck in a long conversation that takes a few minute, but only has like one line that is actually important for the story. Most of the characters are impossible to like, a very few of them are somewhat interesting but get no focus at all. The jokes are awful and trying too hard, not a single joke even made me giggle. It's full of references for things, but none of them is being put there in a smart or funny way, it's like they are only there because they put a goal on this game to have a lot of references. The puzzles also have no logic at all in them, most of them literally require random guessing, yet the achivements require you to get them all right at first try. That pretty much forces you to cheat and look for the solutions online, because it's impossible to randomly guess the solution at your first try when it has no logic behind it (ridiculous things like \"if that Star Wars character would deserve to die, who would need to be the one to kill them?\", that's literally a part of one of the puzzles). The game is also VERY long, it has like 7 episodes, which are really hard to take when the story is so boring and is just full of long dialogs that are not even relevant, and as if the long dialogs are not enough, there are also a lot of pauses in them. {"text": "This game has great visuals, runs well, and always keeps you busy somehow. That good stuff said, I can't say I don't recommend this game without some cons. The gameplay itself is basically Zoo Tycoon 2013 (also by Frontier) but made a little more complex, with the awful plot plopping mechanic replaced by actually terraforming and placing fences. That said, it's still pretty barebones and really nowhere on par with what you'd normally be looking at in this type of game. The management aspects are pretty well done, but the actual building and design aspects are pretty barebones. This isn't necessarily a negative, but if you're coming into this game expecting it to be like Planet Coaster, you will be disappointed. The game hides lots of key information behind cluttered menus. This was also an issue with ZT, but it's not as big of a problem in Evolution. That said, being unable to find something as simple as how many guests you have, or at what capacity you need to place a hotel at, is an issue regardless. With how management-focused the game is, the AI being bad should not come as a surprise, but when the game focuses so heavily on making your dinosaurs happy rather than your guests, seeing that your animals have approximately six animations each makes them very, very repetitive to see. They don't sleep, they don't herd, the fighting is very clunky and unnatural looking, I could go on and on, but I'll honestly say this is probably just a knitpick as someone used to older Tycoon games where details like this were pretty much required. Finally, my biggest problem with this game: It has a lot of bugs that are pretty frequent in occurance, which makes me wonder how much they actually tested this game before release for some of these bugs to be occuring. Camera input keys getting stuck almost constantly when you try to move the camera, All input except scrolling simply being ignored seemingly for no reason, and buildings being damaged but the game giving you no indication are all bugs I've encountered more than once in my few hours of playtime, which makes me wonder if they just didn't have a QA team, or they have never tested a game before. The game has a lot of potential and is fun. I am going to keep playing it, but at this point in time I can't say it's really worth the current price tag. It's worth half the current price at most. Buy it if you like management games when it's on sale, don't waste money buying it at the normal cost.", "appid": "648350", "steamid": "profiles/76561198040822145", "voted_up": false, "votes_up": "11", "votes_funny": 0, "early_access": false, "tstamp_created": 1528804800.0}

{"text": "Игра на любителя!", "appid": "349700", "steamid": "profiles/76561198166785518", "voted_up": false, "votes_up": 0, "votes_funny": 0, "early_access": false, "tstamp_created": 1452081600.0}
{"text": "Depois de jogar por mais de 20 horas, acho que já posso fazer um review sobre o que achei do game até o momento. Por muita sorte, não tive crashes como a maioria teve, mas o desempenho do jogo me decepcionou muito logo de cara. Meu PC atende a todos os requisitos mínimos para rodar o game, mas mesmo assim dificilmente consigo uma taxa de fps superior a 40. Um dia antes do lancamento eu ainda limpei o meu HD com uma formatação de baixo nível, o que descarta qualquer possibilidade de a minha máquina estar \"suja\". A grande maioria dos jogadores concorda que o jogo está muito mal otimizado para PC, e a única esperança é um futuro patch para corrigir isso. Logo que foi lançado para PS4, fiz questão de não assistir a nenhuma das transmissões ao vivo para não estragar a minha surpresa ao jogar. Bem, realmente tive muitas surpresas, mas nem todas foram boas. A primeira delas foi com os gráficos; não são diferentes do que se via nos trailers, mas de certa forma me decepcionaram um pouco. No entanto, apesar de não serem os mais realistas, os gráficos são bons na medida do possível para um jogo onde se explora planetas inteiros. Comecei jogando com o controle do Xbox, mas depois de um tempo achei melhor usar a combinação teclado + mouse, pois acho muito mais prático explorar tudo dessa forma, apesar de o jogo ser totalmente compatível com o controle. Os menus me confundiram logo no início, mas agora já estou bem acostumado. A física do jogo eu achei bem bugada, são várias as vezes em que eu pouso a nave à beira de um precipício ou no topo de uma planta gigante e ela permanece lá paradinha como se estivesse no chão. Aliás, pilotar naves nos planetas é algo bem complicado, principalmente na hora do pouso. Alguns sistemas estelares possuem vários planetas com tamanhos diferentes, e alguns com luas bem menores, mas TODOS têm a mesma força gravitacional! Sério, isso é algo que me incomoda muito. Aqui, posso resumir o jogo em uma única palavra: repetitivo. Antes do lançamento eu já pretendia ficar explorando o máximo de planetas e sistemas, e deixar o objetivo principal do jogo (chegar ao centro da galáxia) para depois. No entanto, depois de algumas horas jogando, é impossível não perceber que a semelhança entre planetas (mesmo os de sistemas diferentes) é muito grande. Não só as características das plantas, mas também as coisas que se faz em cada um, que podem ser resumidas em: - Minerar ítens; - Lutar contra os sentinelas (sempre iguais); - Catalogar plantas e animais; - Localizar bases e instalações; - Encontrar alienígenas nas instalações e aprender palavras do idioma; - Ir até a estação espacial para vender os ítens; - Pousar em outro planeta e fazer tudo de novo. Os ítens que se encontra nos planetas são quase sempre os mesmos, salvo algumas exceções onde se encontra elementos raros. Então, surge outro problema: o sistema de inventário do jogo. Espero estar errado quanto a isso, mas nesse primeiro momento só é possível armazenar os ítens coletados nos inventários da nave e do traje, os quais são ridículamente pequenos. Espero que mais para a frente eu econtre alguma forma de armazenar coisas em algum armazem ou algo parecido, ou que isso seja adicionado através de algum patch. Essa é uma polêmica que já rola muito antes de o jogo ser lançado. Eu, pessoalmente, não curto jogos multiplayer, prefiro jogar sozinho interagindo com NPCs. Porém, antes do lançamento eu concordava com o fato de que tal recurso seria essencial para prolongar a vida útil do jogo. No entanto, após conhecer o game, me pergunto se seria possível implementar um multiplayer tradicional sem fazer com que o jogo perca suas características. Mas o jogo não é composto só de coisas ruins. Deslocar-se de um planeta a outro com a tecnologia de propulsor da nave é algo bem interessante. Os gráficos, apesar de limitados, em alguns momentos conseguem nos presentear com belíssimas paisagens de horizontes com outros planetas ao fundo. A ideia de explorar um cenário praticamente infinito é surreal, ninguém vai visitar todos os planetas e isso faz com que todos os jogadores tenham experiências completamente diferentes. Aos que ainda não compraram e estão na dúvida, recomendo que não comprem, ao menos não nesse momento. Melhor esperar entrar em promoção daqui alguns meses, pois atualmente o valor cobrado é muito alto comparado ao que o jogo oferece. Eu, no entanto, continuarei jogando. Minha curiosidade e interesse em chegar ao centro da galáxia é muito maior do que os aspectos negativos do jogo. Espero poder atualizar essa review futuramente com tópicos melhores. Definitivamente não recomendo para jogadores que não curtem jogos de exploração ou buscam um mata-mata em equipe no espaço. Atualização: 28/11/2016 Depois de muito tempo, finalmente surge a atualização Foundation, trazendo um pouco de esperança para aqueles que, como eu, ainda têm esperança de que No Man's Sky se torne de fato divertido algum dia. Dentre as novidades do update, o que mais me agradou foi o recurso que possibilita a criação de uma base em qualquer planeta visitado. E, de acordo com a desenvolvedora, isso é apenas o começo de uma série de atualizações que trarão várias novidades ao jogo. Tomara! Me sinto um pouco menos deprimido agora.", "appid": "275850", "steamid": "profiles/76561198116118109", "voted_up": false, "votes_up": "90", "votes_funny": "2", "early_access": false, "tstamp_created": 1471262400.0}

M doesn't have any of that - it is so genetic. It almost looks like a DayZ rip off and PUBG (even tho M is much older then PUBG) - but it doesnt feel like one of these games. Maybe it should get more from those games.  I dont know. {"text": "Feels a step in the right direction but still doesn`t feel like a proper CoD game. The menu feels alien and the divison system is really pointless, it just complicates a simple and popular class system that existed in previous CoDs without actually making the game better. It is like having two front doors on your house, you only need one but an extra one is added just for the sake of it and thats how the new class system feels, completely unnecessary and not CoD like. It adds an extra step to the class system for no reason whatsoever. The MvPs all standing together at the end of a match posing is just not CoD for me, I expect it in Halo but it doesn`t suit the game. The gameplay is certainly a big step in the right direction but the UI and certain aspects of the game still feel recycled from recent CoDs that were very unpopular such as Infinite Warfare or Black Ops 3. Exo suits were the worst thing to ever happen to CoD so I`m glad they are gone The music sucks, in particular the lobby music. The lobby music from previous CoDs like MW2 or Bo1/2  is far more memorable and I can still hum it to this day years after playing for the first time. The music in this CoD just lacks something and seems very dull and uninspiring. I can barely keep this lobby music in my mind for 10 minutes and I can still clearly remember the lobby music from other CoDs or the zombies lobby music from B01/B02 years on. I almost feel like this is a bit of a rip off of Battlefield 1 which earns it an extra -1 from me. Bayonet charges are a clear rip off. The guns lack any punch or power and just feel dull and boring to shoot with. I will admit I have not unlocked all the guns but I pick up guns off the floor and try as many as possible and none have impressed me. On most CoDs you find a gun that \"clicks\" with you quickly but this year they all seem crappy and weak. Overall I think the boots on the grounds style returning is a good thing but they are still implementing pointless and un Cod like features which just kills it for me. I think this game will make or break CoD as another unpopular game will undoubtedly be the nail in the coffin for the franchise. The maps are very camper friendly because it is very easy for a camper to sit in one spot and have a steady stream of people running past to kill, it is harder to counter campers on this than on other CoDs due to poor map design. The maps don`t suit the pace or style of CoD. It appears they have gone for aesthetics over function. I can`t really recommend this to veteran CoD players because it`s just more of the same garbage we have seen for the last 4 or so CoDs but in a WW2 skin. There are no exo suits but it still doesnt feel like the CoD I remember. Its definitely better than what we have seen from recent CoDs but not worth the price tag.  The only thing that could redeem this CoD for me would be extremely good zombies but I won`t get my hopes up as the recent attempts of CoD zombies have been pitiful. Is it better than recent CoDs? Yes. And it still sucks. The UI is probably the worst yet. {"text": "Long story short: A slow, disappointing slog that never seems to get anywhere. Civilization VI is a turn-based 4x strategy game. Explore, expand, exploit and exterminate is what the 4x stands for. Explore the land you spawn in, expand you empire by settling in new cities, exploit the land's ressources and exterminate anyone who opposes you. It might sound simple at first, but there are many layers of complexity you have to manage. Build schools to generate Science points, build art museums to generate Culture, etc. The goal of the game is to achieve victory, but you can do it in many ways. Crush your enemies with military might to get a Domination victory, launch a space rocket to get a Science victory, etc. The most interesting aspect is the randomness of it all. The map you play in, as well as the enemy AI are always random and can generate some fun or horrendous gameplay, depending on where you spawn and how far you can expand your empire. To summarize the gameplay, you can say this game is like a blend between Chess and the board game Risk with deeper, more complex mechanics as it spans all known eras of humankind, from Ancient era to modern day Information era. All the descisions you make very early can have positive or negative impact in the far future. Compared to Civ V, the graphics in VI is a massive improvement. Unexplored world map has those \"here be dragons\" drawings. The geography looks more organic and less \"square\" than previous titles. Overall, the world feels more alive. Also, Civ IV fans will probably like the new Wonder animation, which is built live on your terrain instead of showing you a video or static image. Unlike Civ V, the Leaders have a more \"Disney cartoon\" look to them than the realistic Civ 5 leaders. I like Civ 5's leaders more, but those Civ 6 leaders got a chuckle or 2 out of me. In the sound department, I found myself less enchanted by the soundtrack in general since it seems to repeat the same songs. What I found out was that whoever is winning the game has music priority. In exemple, if Canada is leading the game, you will always hear the Canadian National Anthem. Civ 4 and 5 had better musical diversity, segmented in world region and eras. After a couple of games trying to figure out everything, it seems the more I play, the more I descend into hellish madness where I keep stumbling upon details that just makes me say \"why did they do this?\" or \"why did they change that?\". Sadly, there's a character limit to Steam reviews and I have so much to talk about it wouldn't fit  in. For convenience's sake, I'll link a thread I wrote in the Steam forum detailing the many issues I stumbled upon. For integrity's sake, here's a small paragraph highlighting these issues.  Everything takes too long to build or grow. Movement penalty \"skip turn\" spam sucks. Scouts are useless. Builders are almost useless. District management/loyalty system restrains you in how much you grow your cities/empire. Over-complicated Civics when Civ 5 policies were just right. Dead ends in Tech/Civic trees. \"High-Tech\" Barbarian camp spam. Incessant barrage of popups, worse than Civ 5 with DLCs. Ball-busting diplo system, same with city states. Need a mod to see a detailed unit list like Civ 5. Detailed Leader scenes and intro text gone. AI cheats everything: city spam, unit spam, religious unit spam. Diplo Favor/Grievance is useless because AI never listens and never stop doing the things you ask them to stop doing. Spies are annoying as even friendly AI will still spy on you, sabotaging every possible angle of your empire. Wonders have lame buffs compared to Civ 5. Lastly on the technical side, this game has THREE loading screens before you can start playing. Combined together, it can take at least 5 minutes before you start playing, effectively dethroning Killing Floor 2 as \"The Longest Game to Load\". 1 loading screen for the Main Menu, 1 loading screen for the leader intro which is another loading screen. Yes, you read that right, I'm loading another loading screen. Pure ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ cancerous garbage. I can start a Civ V game in less than 2 minutes. I know the graphics are better but I don't think that this facelift justifies these atrocious loading times, even with all graphics set to low. And this graphic fidelity doesn't justify the helicopter takeoff in my PC. Domination win is hard because of terrain layout and unit production times. Religious win is harder because you have to maintain religious pressure everywhere at all times. Culture win is hard because you need Religious Faith currency to buy Great Musician (just wow). Diplomatic Win is easy and totally lifeless. The only sure-shot way of winning the game is either with a Science or Score win. Build a rocket, or spam cities & wonders. This game started out nicely. I had moderate expections and hopes that it would improve from Civ 5, without holding my breath too much. But the more I play, the more I hate it because it's just a condensing pile of annoyance that never seems to stop. I recommend this game for liberal tree-hugging peace-mongerer who like to micro-manage popups. As a biased fan of Civ 5, I cannot recommend this game because it strays in too many directions, seemingly forgeting what this game was supposed to be about... Explore, expand, exploit and exterminate. Now it feels more like \"Explore, expand, get exploited and manage schizophrenic diplomacy\". 4/10", "appid": "289070", "steamid": "profiles/76561197989933933", "voted_up": false, "votes_up": "13", "votes_funny": 0, "early_access": false, "tstamp_created": 1578830400.0}

{"text": "The gameplay is actually decent, which is something i didnt expect from this game. Shooting feels fun, it is responsive and character wise there are slower tankier robots, faster robots with teleport abilities, snipers, demolition type robots and so on. Some of abilities resemble other Hero Shooters, but they arent that blatant to be called of as a complete copy. Servers okay for me so far. But that is pretty much all about it, for now. There are only 7 different characters and they dont really have any kind of personality and arent memorable, something which is an important aspect for these type of games, it adds a lot of better production quality feel and sometimes makes people keep playing on just because they like the character's personality. They look quite bland now, and they are all more or less basic looking robots. Naming them, adding a bit of backstory, few voice lines and more detailed look goes a long way (at least for me, because i always came back to Dirty Bomb to play few matches with Sparks or Phantom). Even the maps look very basic, they are metallic looking empty rooms with dosens of hallways. And sadly, there is a catch, its another issue.. more serious but also a very common one. Each character has individual skill tree which requires quite the hefty amount of in game money (V-money) to unlock. While these upgrades can technically be unlocked for free, they cost quite a lot of V-money, and considering that you need to unlock dosens of these for each character individually and that there is a daily limit of how much money you can make (200 Vmoney, cost of one level 1 skill), makes it a borderline p2w game in my opinion. Although, this system has a good side as well, which is being able to purchase cosmetic items with same V-money which is earned from matches. Optimization isnt really the best for the graphics you are getting here, but you will probably be able to make it playable with setting tweaking on older computers. To sum it up, CityBattle | Virtual Earth actually has somewhat decent core game mechanics, shooting is fun and combat is fast enough, but it fails to deliver good production quality with memorable, balanced characters and interesting maps. It has interesting in game currency system though, where there is only one currency and you can buy everything with it, even the skins, but there is a daily limit on how much you can earn of it for free. Sadly this currency is crucial for skill tree upgrades, which are very expensive and offer powerful upgrades. Most of people consider it \"pay to advance\", but i'd call it p2w because of the amounts of grind required and daily limits locked in place. I was actually going to give this game a positive review, and while i dont mind daily limit of 200 V-money, i greatly mind the skill trees which offer direct upgrades (most of times) and offset the matches, they just dont deserve a place in serious first person shooter games solely focused on PvP.", "appid": "611020", "steamid": "profiles/76561198121525707", "voted_up": false, "votes_up": "20", "votes_funny": 0, "early_access": false, "tstamp_created": 1539086400.0}

{"text": "Die Freude über ein neues TKKG Spiel war nur von kurzer Dauer. Zwar ließen die recht ansprechende Grafik und die professionelle Vertonung durch die Originalsprecher der Hörspielreihe (obwohl ich die Stimmen aus den alten PC Spielen auch gerne mochte) auf ein gelungenes Revival hoffen, aber beim Spielen zeigte sich dann schnell, dass die „Feuerprobe“ nichts mehr mit den Spielen von damals gemein hat. Spannung und knifflige Rätzel stelle ich mir echt anders vor: Klößchen hat 20 Tafeln Schokolade durchs Zimmer geschmissen! Wenn das nicht mal eine Aufgabe für den sportlichen Tim ist, er kann sie blitzschnell wieder aufsammeln. Der MüBO fallen 30 Bälle runter! Kein Problem Karl der Computer kann sie alle finden. Das Personal der Villa Sauerlich verteilt– warum auch immer –Billardkugeln im ganzen Haus! Die wieder ordentlich auf dem Billardtisch zu drapieren klingt doch nach einer aufregenden Beschäftigung für Klößchen (wobei ich mich schon frage: wenn Klößchen doch offenbar so gerne Sachen wegräumt, warum muss dann Tim seine ganzen Schokoladentafeln einsammeln?). Ein unbekannter bittet ein junges Mädchen in sein Haus – Gaby nimmt diese dubiose Einladung ohne langes Zögern an und – na wer kanns erraten? Richtig! - sammelt, ganz nach dem Vorbild ihrer männlichen Kollegen gänzlich unnützen Kram ein: 27 Plastiktüten, 7 Modellautos, 9 Glühbirnen und ein paar Golfbälle. Für den „Fall“ sind dann übrigens sämtliche oben aufgezählte Gegenstände völlig belanglos. Es sind keine Hinweise, Beweise oder sonst wie nützliche Gegenstände die man benötigt um irgendwo rein oder raus zukommen oder wichtige Informationen zu erhalten. Kein Befragen von Zeugen oder Verdächtigen, keine unterschiedlichen Orte auf dem Stadtplan (stattdessen ist jeder der Vier an einem festen Ort positioniert an welchem er dann „ermittelt“), kein Herr Peper, keine Berta und kein Apotheker Brodonski – wobei das Fehlen dieser alten Bekannten wahrscheinlich einfach eine Frage der Urheberrechte ist, da kann man wohl nix machen. Kurz gesagt, das Ganze ist eher ein Wimmelbildspiel und dann nicht mal ein gutes. Denn mitunter sind die zu „suchenden“ Gegenstände alle auf einem Haufen und man muss einfach 20-mal auf die gleiche Stelle kicken. WARUM? Ich versteh es einfach nicht! Unterbrochen wird das sinnlose rumgeklicke lediglich durch einige Dialoge und den, mal mehr mal weniger nervigen, Minispielen. Schade, schade ich hatte so auf ein neues „altes“ TKKG Computer Spiel gehofft, aber hier wird nur wahllos Zeug aufgesammelt und aufgeräumt statt richtig ermittelt, passend dazu gibt es übrigens eine Stelle im Spiel in der sich Karl als Putzfrau verkleiden muss. „TKKG: Der Putzkolonnen Simulator 2019“ – wäre wohl der passendere Titel für dieses Spiel gewesen.", "appid": "1104870", "steamid": "profiles/76561198017218513", "voted_up": false, "votes_up": "1", "votes_funny": 0, "early_access": false, "tstamp_created": 1604232000.0}
{"text": "El juego ni bien lo empezas a jugar esta buenisimo, entretenido, te engancha al toque. Pero a la larga se torna super repetitivo. Cada ves hay menos gente jugando, lo que lleva a que tarde mas en buscar una partida, y las partidas que encuentran si sos de Argentina, como es mi caso, encontras con 220 de ping para arriba, muy dificil que encunetres con menos de eso. {"text": "Was für ein Mist hier passiert ist, geht auf keine Kuhhaut, wie man so schön sagt. Was die mit dem Spiel abliefern, hat ein ähnliches Gewicht wie Blizzard's Diablo Immortal Ankündigung oder Bethesda mit ihrem verhunzten Fallout 76. Tagelang gibt es neue Termine, aber Kommunikation sucht man ansonsten vergebens. Weder auf Steam, noch auf den offiziellen Kanälen kommt irgend etwas Neues. Wann ist das Spiel nun endlich kaufbar und spielbar? Die Streamer und Zuschauer sitzen Stundenlang vorm Stream, nix passiert, kein Release Heute. Bei jeder weiteren Verschiebung auf Tage später das gleiche Dilemma. Alle werden zunehmend angepisster, ob Twitch, Twitter, Steam Forum. Nachdem dann erneut nur über Twitter kommuniziert wurde (immerhin) das am 22.12.2018 der finale Release sein wird, hatte kaum jemand noch die Erwartung das dies tatsächlich passieren würde. Ja, Atlas kam tatsache raus, zur späten Nachtzeit. Nur ging es dann weiter mit dem Mist. Das Spiel war nun kaufbar bei Steam, mit Verspätung. Die Atlas Server sollten online sein. Doch dann ging der Steam Service ging für knapp eine Stunde down. Erst kauften Spieler das Spiel ohne Rabatt (wurde erst minuten später Rabattiert -17%). Diese Käufer sollten das Spiel refunden und Neu Kaufen, war die Empfehlung. Dann konnte niemand das Spiel kaufen und wenn, dann hing man trotz Kauf in der Warteschleife und konnte das Spiel nicht installieren. Klickte man mehrmals auf Kaufen, gelangte man auf eine Warteschleife von 30min - 1 Std. und konnte erst dann Kaufen. *Zu viele Käufe innerhalb der letzten Stunde*. Ja, wegen \"reload\" und \"kaufen\" geklicke. Die Streamer hatten einen exklusiven \"Test Server\". Nachdem der gewiped wurde ging mit den offiziellen Servern aber nix. Disconnects ohne Ende. Auf Twitter ständig neue Updates, es verschiebt sich erneut, mehrmals weil sie Probleme haben mit den Servern. Das Spiel währendessen herunter geladen (3 Uhr morgens) installiert, doch die Server für die Streamer waren mittlerweile offline. Dann wieder online, oder auch nicht. Offline! Die Streamer bekommen einen eigenen Server gehostet, damit sie spielen können und der Welt da draußen zeigen können: schaut mal, so wäre es wenn man Atlas aktuell spielen könnte. Die Käufer des Spiels sitzen im Hauptmenu und kommen auf keinen Server. Die Streamer Gemeinde hat das Spiel nicht gekauft, warum auch. Kaum sind die Server nachts um 4Uhr dann endlich erreichbar, sind die auch schon voll, egal welcher Server. Nach ewigen Versuchen einem beizutreten, endlich im Spiel. Aber... es wird noch besser. Zwei Drittel der Spieler auf dem Server liegen nur herum und schlafen. Rubber banding, mieserabler Ping von 255 obwohl der Server vorher 40ms angezeigt hatte. Obendrein ruckelt das Spiel auf max. Details enorm! Ich konnte in Freeport kaum laufen geschweige denn irgendetwas Erkunden, es ging einfach nicht bei dem Ruckeln. Hab dann die Grafik komplett auf low gestellt, der gleiche Mist. Hab dann noch andere Server probiert, nix geht. Die Streamer spielen derweil flüssig Atlas auf einem privaten Server. Großartig. 4:30 Uhr dann Spiel beendet, kurzes Ruckel Video hochgeladen auf YT und auf Steam den Refund eingeleitet. Was ein Spaß, nie wieder mein Herren! Atlas ist nahezu 1:1 Ark: Survival Evolved. Man könnte von einer \"Total Conversion\" mit Piraten Setting sprechen. Die gleiche Datei-/Ordnerstruktur, Spielgröße von 100 GB, identische Spielmechaniken wie in Ark. Das im Hauptmenu beim anschließen eines Controllers das Menu von Ark   erscheint und Atlas als aktivierbarer DLC läuft, setzt dem Ganzen dann die Krone auf. War Atlas ein geplanter DLC für Ark? Offensichtlich. Stattdessen verkauft man Atlas als eigenständiges Spiel im Early Access und gründet dafür extra eine Tochterfirma und zieht einen Teil der Entwickler von Ark ab für die Entwicklung. Sollte es ein Flop werden, macht man das Studio einfach dicht. Ein Mieserabler Early Access Release und schlechte Kommunikation taten ihr übriges. Schafft man es dann mal ins Spiel. Schlechte Spiel Performance, selbst mit High-end PC gefühlte 5 fps. Die Grafische Qualität der Strukturen und Texturen schwankt von mieserabel bis anschaubar. Einen Einzelspielermodus gibt es defacto nicht, nur Multiplayer. An Solospieler richtet sich Atlas eh nicht, da es nur bedingt alleine gespielt werden kann. Und nur bis zu einem gewissen Fortschritt im Spiel handelbar ist. Kaum oder schlecht erreichbare Server mit hohem Ping. Nahezu unspielbar unter diesen Bedingungen. Hinzu kommt das die Werte für Essen und Trinken enorm hoch sind. Bedeutet man muss ständig Essen und Trinken, obendrein verderben die Ressourcen unglaublich schnell. Es gibt außerdem ein \"Vitamin-System\", wo man auf die einzelnen bunten Balken acht geben muss, und entsprechende Nahrung zu sich nehmen muss um Gesund zu bleiben. Zu kompliziert in dieser virtuellen Welt. Ich kann nur abraten zu diesem Zeitpunkt von Atlas.", "appid": "834910", "steamid": "profiles/76561197971611118", "voted_up": false, "votes_up": "25", "votes_funny": "1", "early_access": true, "tstamp_created": 1545566400.0}

{"text": "Сижу недоумеваю: Как же меня смогла обойти эта замечательная игра в 2к16. Целый год мне приходилось играть во второсортные игры, типа GTA, проходить всяких там среднечковых бэтменов, когда шедевр был буквально перед носом весь тот год. Обо всём по порядку. Тут вам и внезапные колдуны, летящие со своими волшебными колбами, и грозовые тучи которые, зачастую, портят вам весь прогресс (нет) и всякие многочисленные проходимцы (жители городка), которые не очень то и вкусные (не все) 50/50.
